name: 1618_A. Polycarp and Sums of Subsequences
description:
Polycarp had an array a of 3 positive integers. He wrote out the sums of all non-empty subsequences of this array, sorted them in non-decreasing order, and got an array b of 7 integers.

For example, if a = \{1, 4, 3\}, then Polycarp wrote out 1, 4, 3, 1 + 4 = 5, 1 + 3 = 4, 4 + 3 = 7, 1 + 4 + 3 = 8. After sorting, he got an array b = \{1, 3, 4, 4, 5, 7, 8\}.

Unfortunately, Polycarp lost the array a. He only has the array b left. Help him to restore the array a.

Input

The first line contains one integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 5000) — the number of test cases.

Each test case consists of one line which contains 7 integers b_1, b_2, ..., b_7 (1 ≤ b_i ≤ 10^9; b_i ≤ b_{i+1}). 

Additional constraint on the input: there exists at least one array a which yields this array b as described in the statement.

Output

For each test case, print 3 integers — a_1, a_2 and a_3. If there can be several answers, print any of them.

Example

Input


5
1 3 4 4 5 7 8
1 2 3 4 5 6 7
300000000 300000000 300000000 600000000 600000000 600000000 900000000
1 1 2 999999998 999999999 999999999 1000000000
1 2 2 3 3 4 5


Output


1 4 3
4 1 2
300000000 300000000 300000000
999999998 1 1
1 2 2

Note

The subsequence of the array a is a sequence that can be obtained from a by removing zero or more of its elements.

Two subsequences are considered different if index sets of elements included in them are different. That is, the values of the elements don't matter in the comparison of subsequences. In particular, any array of length 3 has exactly 7 different non-empty subsequences.
repair_prompt:
Polycarp possessed a collection a consisting of 3 positive numbers and enumerated the totals of all non-empty subsequences of this collection, organized them in ascending order, and obtained an array b of 7 numbers.

For example, if a = \{1, 4, 3\}, then Polycarp wrote out 1, 4, 3, 1 + 4 = 5, 1 + 3 = 4, 4 + 3 = 7, 1 + 4 + 3 = 8. He then sorted these sums, and as a result, he got an array b = \{1, 3, 4, 4, 5, 7, 8\}.

Unfortunately, Polycarp lost the array a. He only has the array b left. Help him to restore the array a. Demonstrate that the order of original array a can be disregarded when reconstructing.

Input

The first line contains one integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 5000) — the number of test cases.

Each test case consists of one line which contains 7 integers b_1, b_2, ..., b_7 (1 ≤ b_i ≤ 10^9; b_i ≤ b_{i+1}). 

Additional constraint on the input: there exists at least one array a which yields this array b as described in the statement.

Output

For each test case, print 3 integers — a_1, a_2 and a_3. If there can be several answers, print any of them.

Example

Input


5
1 3 4 4 5 7 8
1 2 3 4 5 6 7
300000000 300000000 300000000 600000000 600000000 600000000 900000000
1 1 2 999999998 999999999 999999999 1000000000
1 2 2 3 3 4 5


Output


1 4 3
4 1 2
300000000 300000000 300000000
999999998 1 1
1 2 2

Note

The subsequence of the array a is a sequence that can be obtained from a by removing zero or more of its elements.

Two subsequences are considered different if index sets of elements included in them are different. That is, the values of the elements don't matter in the comparison of subsequences. In particular, any array of length 3 has exactly 7 different non-empty subsequences.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
completion:
def restore_array_a(test_cases):
    results = []
    for b in test_cases:
        # According to the plan, derive a_1, a_2, a_3 from b
        a_1 = b[0]
        a_2 = b[1]
        a_3 = b[6] - a_1 - a_2
        results.append((a_1, a_2, a_3))
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        b = list(map(int, data[index:index+7]))
        test_cases.append(b)
        index += 7
    
    results = restore_array_a(test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result[0], result[1], result[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def restore_array_a(test_cases):
    results = []
    for b in test_cases:
        # According to the plan, a_1 = b[0], a_2 = b[1], a_3 = b[6] - (a_1 + a_2)
        a_1 = b[0]
        a_2 = b[1]
        a_3 = b[6] - (a_1 + a_2)
        results.append((a_1, a_2, a_3))
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1

    for _ in range(t):

main()

def restore_array_a(test_cases):
    results = []
    for b in test_cases:
        # According to the plan:
        a1 = b[0]  # The smallest element in b
        a2 = b[1]  # The second smallest element in b
        a3 = b[6] - a1 - a2  # The largest element in b minus a1 and a2
        results.append((a1, a2, a3))
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        b = list(map(int, data[index:index+7]))
        test_cases.append(b)
        index += 7
    
    results = restore_array_a(test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result[0], result[1], result[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def restore_array(test_cases):
    results = []
    for b in test_cases:
        # The largest element in b is the sum of all elements in a
        a3 = b[6]
        # The smallest element in b is one of the elements of a
        a1 = b[0]
        # The second smallest element in b is another element of a
        a2 = b[1]
        # The third element in b is the sum of the two smallest elements
        # We can use this to verify our choice of a1 and a2
        if a1 + a2 != b[2]:
            a2 = b[2]
        results.append((a1, a2, a3 - a1 - a2))
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        b = list(map(int, data[index:index+7]))
        test_cases.append(b)
        index += 7
    
    results = restore_array(test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        print(' '.join(map(str, result)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

        # a_3 is the largest element minus the sum of a_1 and a_2

def restore_array_a(test_cases):
    results = []
    for b in test_cases:
        # The smallest element in b is one of the elements of a
        a1 = b[0]
        # The largest element in b is the sum of all elements of a
        a1_a2_a3 = b[6]
        # The second largest element in b is the sum of the two largest elements of a
        a2_a3 = b[5]
        
        # Calculate the other two elements
        a2 = a2_a3 - a1
        a3 = a1_a2_a3 - a1 - a2
        
        results.append((a1, a2, a3))
    
    return results

    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        b = list(map(int, data[index:index+7]))
        test_cases.append(b)
        index += 7
    
    results = restore_array_a(test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result[0], result[1], result[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
Round_0.report: The compilation output of the preceding code is: Code Test Passed.

prompt:
Polycarp possessed a collection a consisting of 3 positive numbers and enumerated the totals of all non-empty subsequences of this collection, organized them in ascending order, and obtained an array b of 7 numbers.

For example, if a = \{1, 4, 3\}, then Polycarp wrote out 1, 4, 3, 1 + 4 = 5, 1 + 3 = 4, 4 + 3 = 7, 1 + 4 + 3 = 8. He then sorted these sums, and as a result, he got an array b = \{1, 3, 4, 4, 5, 7, 8\}.

Unfortunately, Polycarp lost the array a. He only has the array b left. Help him to restore the array a. Demonstrate that the order of original array a can be disregarded when reconstructing.

Input

The first line contains one integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 5000) — the number of test cases.

Each test case consists of one line which contains 7 integers b_1, b_2, ..., b_7 (1 ≤ b_i ≤ 10^9; b_i ≤ b_{i+1}). 

Additional constraint on the input: there exists at least one array a which yields this array b as described in the statement.

Output

For each test case, print 3 integers — a_1, a_2 and a_3. If there can be several answers, print any of them.

Example

Input


5
1 3 4 4 5 7 8
1 2 3 4 5 6 7
300000000 300000000 300000000 600000000 600000000 600000000 900000000
1 1 2 999999998 999999999 999999999 1000000000
1 2 2 3 3 4 5


Output


1 4 3
4 1 2
300000000 300000000 300000000
999999998 1 1
1 2 2

Note

The subsequence of the array a is a sequence that can be obtained from a by removing zero or more of its elements.

Two subsequences are considered different if index sets of elements included in them are different. That is, the values of the elements don't matter in the comparison of subsequences. In particular, any array of length 3 has exactly 7 different non-empty subsequences.
